398. Davis Mary Elizabeth (Mrs. W. Harford)
"Mary Elizabeth Davis" (nee Clark). Born in Denbigh, North Wales of English parents, in 1874. Thus, now, 71 years old.

Father; S.A. Clark, Architect & Builder. Emigrated to Canada—-with his family----- from Croyden, England, in April 1883.

"I was just nine years old when I began my 'pioneer' life, by arriving at Regina—in a rain storm—on May 1st 1883.

I always think of the Regina of that day as "A number of tents surrounded entirely by mud," but believe, according to other reports that there were some "frame"? dwellings, also.

In a few days my father obtained a "Homestead" in what is now known as the Foxleigh District and we proceeded to it in true traditional pioneer fashion, in a 'covered waggon', drawn by a yoke of half broken oxen. One of the 'high lights', of that journey was the 'fording' of 'Boggy Creek',------then in flood----- at a point not far from Victoria Plains.

We spent our first Summer in a tent & had no neighbors. According to eyewitness, we were the only people in the world.

Later on, Father and I cut logs in the 'Bluffs', and built a log cabin. During those years of 'Homesteading', almost every usual, and some unusual, experiences common to Pioneers were mine, from fighting prairie fires, round haystacks and house, to fighting cold and starvation in the Winter months. "Mary Elizabeth Davis" (nee Clark), Born in Bentleigh, North Wales of English parents, in 1874. Thus, now, 71 years old.

Father: S.A. Clark, Architect & Builder. Emigrated to Canada—-with his family—-from Croydon, England, in April 1883.

"I was just nine years old when I began my 'pioneer' life, by arriving at Regina—in a rain storm—on May 1st, 1883.

I always think of the Regina of that day as "A number of tents surrounded entirely by mud," but believe, according to other reports that there were some "frame" dwellings, also.

In a few days my father obtained a "Homestead" in what is now known as the Foxleigh District and we proceeded to it in true traditional pioneer fashion, in a "covered wagon," drawn by a team of half-broken oxen. One of the "high lights" of that journey was the "fording" of Boggy Creek!——then in flood——at a point not far from Victoria Plains.

We spent our first Summer in a tent & had no neighbors.

According to eyewitness, we were the only people in the world.

Later on, we her and I cut logs in the "Bluff," and built a log cabin. During those years of "Homesteading," almost every usual, and some unusual experiences common to pioneers were mine—from fighting prairie fires round haystacks and house, to fighting cold and starvation in the winter months, from being nursemaid to a new little brother, who arrived mysteriously one stormy September night, to building a sod stable, driving the oxen, and making...
and stacking, hay. (There is much here, Joyce which you would like in detail, but I am sure that it would not be suitable for your purpose, so will pass on, for now.)

In the Autumn of 1886, we moved into Regina to live and the next year I went to work in the office of the "Regina Leader". The other children went to school and found themselves not so far behind other children of their age, thanks to a good and clever father, who was never too busy, or tired, to answer our questions or to fill our evenings with spelling and arithmetic tests, history and geography lessons, and endless 'reading aloud', from good books.

I was 13 when I went into the "Leader". In a sense it was my 'High School'. I learned to set type, to fold and bind magazines, and what I did best, and most, read copy, by the hour. I was 'Copy reader' for that Pioneer Newspaperman, Author, Orator, and Politician Nicholas Flood Davin, and very proud of the fact.

The evenings were full of work at home, helping my invalid mother, and in the fall of 1890, I came home, altogether. In December of that year my mother died, leaving me with father, and six younger brothers and sisters to keep house for. I found it a full time job.

Five years later an old Aunt came from Scotland, to live with us, and I went to work again, and to play also, sometimes. In the October of 1897, I was married to W. Harford Davis, late of Orleton Worcestershire, England, and went once again to the 'Foxleigh', Dis., where his farm was situated.

During those years after my mother's death I went to St. Paul's Church, Regina, teaching in the S.S. for several years, and singing days. We had the privilege also of helping to bring an Anglican Church.

In the Autumn of 1866, we moved into Regina to live and the next year I went to work in the office of the "Regina Leader."

The other children went to school and found themselves not so far behind other children of their age, thanks to a good and clever father, who was never too busy, tired, to answer our questions or to fill our evenings with spelling and arithmetic tests, history and geography lessons, and endless 'reading aloud', from good books.

I was 13, when I went into the "Leader." In a sense it was my 'High School'. I learned to set type, to fold and bind magazines, and what I did best, and most, 'read copy', by the hour. I was 'Copy reader' for that Pioneer Newspaperman, Author, Orator, and Politician Nicholas Flood Davin, and very proud of the fact.

The evenings were full of work at home, helping my invalid mother, and in the fall of 1890, I came home, altogether. In December of that year my mother died, leaving me with father, and six younger brothers and sisters to keep house for. I found it a full time job.

Five years later an old Aunt came from Scotland, to live with us, and I went to work again, and to play also sometimes. In the October of 1897, I was married to W. Harford Davis late of Worcestershire, England, and went once again to the Foxleight, Dis., where his farm was situated.

During those years after my mother's death I went to St. Paul's Church, Regina, teaching in the S.S. for several years, and singing days. We had the privilege also of helping to bring an Anglican Church...
So now I was on a farm again, and very glad of it, for I always loved the prairies. Although many years later than my first experience of Prairie farming, yet the prairie wife was faced still with what we should now consider very primitive conditions. There were no labor-saving devices, no telephone, no P.O., nearer than Regina and only the old horse and buggy to cover the long trips to town.

It was just at the end of a period of bad 'crop years', so there was no money, either, and the diet was of fried pork, potato, and dried apple, almost incomprehensible now-a-days. However in spite of these things, hard work, and a good deal of sickness, my husband and I built up a very happy home which we tried to share with our neighbors.

Six children were born to us, but only two are now living. These are Mrs. J.A. King, of Victoria Plains and Mrs. Ben Lemon of Zehner.

Women bore their children in their own homes in those days, often indeed generally without the aid of doctor or professional nurse as even if these were summoned the "Stork" frequently arrived before they did. I like to think now, of the times when I was able to go to a sister woman whose hour had come upon her, and of the dear babies usually washed and dressed, before Father returned from his slow and anxious journey to Regina. To think also of the Debating Club, we organized, and belonged to, of the many picnics, dances, Christmas Tree Dramatic Societies, and suchlike neighborly activities which my husband and I were instrumental in beginning, in those far off, distant days. We had the privilege also of helping to bring an Anglican Church...

All the pros and cons were discussed in our home---- with the young parson from Condie, and Mr Will Cullam----------Mr Davis was the first Churchwarden, and I was Organist. The early Services were held in the 'Stirling' School house; but later on Mr Davis designed, and the men of the district built, the present Church. I think that would be forty-three years ago.

1. Your full name: MARY ELIZABETH DAVIS (BET CLARK)
2. Your address: 2331 Montague St., Regina, Sask.
3. Date: April 26, 1952
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) DENBIGH, N. WALES
5. What was your father's name and occupation? SEPTIMUS ALFRED CLARK, Architect & Builder
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) April, 1883.
   (At that time, N.W.T.)
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. N. WALES until 8 years of age, then WORCESTER, and LONDON, ENGLAND.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.) 9 years old.
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   (a) Hope of improving our financial circumstances.
   (b) Doctor's orders that my mother leave the damp English climate.
   (c) My Father's adventurous spirit. Also certain pamphlets, circulated at that time describing CANADA as a sort of "El Dorado".
10. How did you learn about the West? (through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?).
    From all three sources mentioned.
    More particularly, from reading.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to refer to your third question if you would rather not or you may use "I was in my teens," etc.) 9 years old.

9. That were your reasons for coming West?
   (a) Hope of improving our financial circumstances
   (b) Doctor's orders that my mother leave the damp English climate
   (c) My mother's adventurous spirit. Also, I am fond of adventure and thought Canada as a good place to build a home.

10. Have you learned from the West through other people? (Writing about 1911)

Form all three answers, mention:

My particularity, Farmsteadings.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

That we were extremely anxious; especially as my mother was an invalid, & there were young children to consider.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

Father, Mother, 3 sisters, 1 brother.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Railway from London to Liverpool, afterwards ship. The "Allan Liner Parisian," on her maiden voyage. Then Railway from HALIFAX to Regina, & Ox Cart to our homestead.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)

Stormy weather & seasickness. The extreme misery of the crowded steerage passengers. (We travelled "Intermediate.") Arrival at HALIFAX. One poor woman with little boy waiting there anxiously for her husband—who had come to CANADA some months earlier—to meet her. Our train journey. No sleeping or eating arrangements. All work until when we got to WINNIPEG where we spent a week in our immigrant shed. On to REGINA, then the end of steel.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

In Regina, at a big TENT HOTEL kept by a kind proprietor named MCKAY. Later on we pitched a tent on what is now S. RAILWAY Co. Wagon.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Section 22, Township 19 Range 19 W. 2nd

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Balgonie, a village. From 1922 to 1944. In Regina from 1886 to 1897. & again from 1944 to 1952.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Not at all before. Since in a number of minor ways. I worked in the EDITOR Office of the "REGINA LEADER" (N.F.DAVIN) for a number of years.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

Quite a number, on my husband's recommendation.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

We came together in April 1883.
My brother A.H. Clark was Saskatoon's first Druggist.
Another, F.J. Clark at Kindersley.
Sister, LILIAN E. KILLOUGH, at Pense, Sask. She was the wife of Captain Killough, of Niel Rebellion (1885).

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stand out in your memory which you would like to record?

Yes, several, but space here will not permit full details; i.e., Brave Joe fighting in the birth of a baby brother during a gale storm, no doctor, nurse, or any help outside the family; also experiences during Winter of 1884, when my mother and children were almost frozen & starved to death, alone in a pine log cabin on the prairie, etc.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? by what means of travel?

No! Occasionally by Ox Cart, but chiefly "SHANK'S PONY," i.e., by walking.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My father was Alderman on Regina in the early 1890s, also Head of Govt. Public Works Department 1895-96-97. WHARFORD DAVIS, MUNICIPAL SECRETARY—For R.M. Edenwold 1887 for 25 years, Churchwarden & School Trustee, for 30. I have always been active in the Anglican Women's Auxiliary. Prior for 25 years, etc.

39. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

I have an old letter a long time. It was written by someone in 1883.

Am now re-copying "Prairie Reminiscences of 1883-84." Will send you a copy if you are interested.

Would you or the person who owns them either

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying? Yes.

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon? Yes, preferably Regina.

CHILDREN: Mrs. J. A. King, Victoria Plains, Saskatchewan; B. Lemon, Zehner, Saskatchewan; Mrs. A. T. Tenker, Regina, Saskatchewan; Miss R. J. King, R.N. (Surgical), Regina, Saskatchewan; F. M. King, Laboratory Technician, Regina, Saskatchewan; B. H. Lemon, Farmer, Zehner; J. C. Lemon, Schoolboy, Book-keeper, Regina.

GRANDCHILDREN: R. F. Lemon, Student, Regina.

What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

Good Roads, Good Farms, A Higher Standard of Education & Living generally. Nothing when I came here—Churches, Schools, Community Halls.
